title: Is there a sans serif that works for print body copy?
content:
Hi all,  
I'm working on a magazine supplement and I was asked to set the body copy in a "modern, classy sans-serif font." Yeah, I know, modern and classy...  
I've set it in Gotham for the moment, but I was wondering if anyone has an idea for a typeface that will work better or any tips for making Gotham and sans-serif in general more readable as body copy.  
Thanks in advance!
author: RaizelDesign

comments.content:
Legato has the best chance.

Something like Gotham is to be avoided.

hhp
Thanks. I don't have that one. What do you think of Whitney?

Perhaps also FF Meta.  
Fonts at MyFonts tagged "book text" and "sans" [https://www.myfonts.com/search/tag%3A%28%22book+text%22+sans%29/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317101228/https:/www.myfonts.com/search/tag%3A%28%22book+text%22+sans%29/fonts/ "https://www.myfonts.com/search/tag%3A%28%22book+text%22+sans%29/fonts/")  
But I have not seen a good relative rating of how well they actually work for extended text.  
Don

I think Whitney is certainly better than Gotham, but it doesn't have Legato's secret ingredient – see my review here:  
 [http://typographica.org/on-typography/our-favorite-typefaces-of-2004/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317101228/http:/typographica.org/on-typography/our-favorite-typefaces-of-2004/ "http://typographica.org/on-typography/our-favorite-typefaces-of-2004/")

Thanks, I'll try them all out. I like verlag, too, I just think it can get uncomfortable if reading a huge chunk of it (I've also, personally, used it too much, I think.)
